title: Recording Transactions
ques: ABC Ltd. purchased office supplies for $500 in cash. Record the transaction in the journal entry format.
explanation:
To record this transaction: 
- ***Office Supplies*** is an asset account, and it is increasing, so we ***debit*** it.
- ***Cash*** is also an asset, but it is decreasing, so we ***credit*** it.
- The journal entry follows the accounting equation ***Assets = Liabilities + Equity***.

title: General Ledger & Subsidiary Ledgers
ques: Post the following journal entry to the General Ledger: ABC Ltd. purchased equipment worth $2,000 on credit from XYZ Inc.

answer.content:
Equipment Account:
Date       | Description         | Debit ($) | Credit ($)
------------------------------------------------------------
2025-04-02 | Purchased Equipment | 2,000     | 

Accounts Payable Account:
Date       | Description         | Debit ($) | Credit ($)
------------------------------------------------------------
2025-04-02 | XYZ Inc. (Equipment)|           | 2,000

explanation:
To post this transaction in the ***General Ledger***:
- The ***Equipment account*** (an asset) increases, so it is ***debited***.
- The ***Accounts Payable account*** (a liability) increases, so it is ***credited***.
- This reflects that the company has purchased equipment but has not yet paid for it.

title: T-Accounts
ques: Use T-Accounts to analyze the impact of a $1,200 rent payment in cash.
explanation:
In ***T-Accounts***:
- The ***Cash*** account decreases, so we record ***1,200 in the Credit side***.
- The ***Rent Expense*** account increases, so we record ***1,200 in the Debit side***.
- This maintains the balance in the double-entry bookkeeping system.

title: Adjusting & Closing Entries
ques: XYZ Ltd. earned $5,000 in revenue but has not yet received payment. Record the adjusting entry.
explanation:
This adjusting entry ensures revenue is recorded when earned:
- ***Accounts Receivable*** (an asset) is ***debited*** because the company expects to receive cash later.
- ***Revenue*** is ***credited*** to reflect earned income.
- Adjusting entries help match revenue with expenses in the same accounting period.

ques: XYZ Ltd. paid $1,200 for utilities. Record the journal entry for this transaction.

title: General Ledger & Subsidiary Ledgers
ques: Post the following journal entry to the General Ledger: ABC Ltd. received $3,000 in cash for services rendered.
explanation:
To post this transaction in the ***General Ledger***:
- The ***Cash account*** (an asset) increases, so it is ***debited***.
- The ***Service Revenue account*** (income) increases, so it is ***credited***.

title: T-Accounts
ques: Use T-Accounts to analyze the impact of a $800 cash payment for advertising expense.
explanation:
In ***T-Accounts***:
- The ***Cash*** account decreases, so we record ***800 in the Credit side***.
- The ***Advertising Expense*** account increases, so we record ***800 in the Debit side***.

title: Adjusting & Closing Entries
ques: ABC Ltd. has earned $1,500 of interest revenue but has not yet received payment. Record the adjusting entry.
explanation:
This adjusting entry recognizes earned interest revenue:
- ***Interest Receivable*** (an asset) is ***debited*** because it reflects money owed to the company.
- ***Interest Revenue*** is ***credited*** to record the earned income.

title: Recording Transactions
ques: DEF Ltd. paid $900 for insurance premium for 6 months in advance. Record the journal entry for this transaction.
explanation:
This journal entry reflects the prepaid insurance payment:
- ***Prepaid Insurance*** is an asset account, and it increases, so we ***debit*** it.
- ***Cash*** decreases as a result of the payment, so we ***credit*** it.

title: General Ledger & Subsidiary Ledgers

title: Recording Transactions
